First, we have to find out the weighted average cost of capital of debt-equity ratio which we denote with $WD$, where the cost of equity $CE$ is $10\%$, equity $E$ is $1$, debt-equity ratio $DE$ is $0.60$ and the after-tax cost of debt $AD$ is $4.6\%$

$$\begin{align*}
WD&=\biggl(CE \times \frac{E}{1+DE}\biggl) + \biggl(AD \times \frac{DE}{1+DE}\biggl)\\[12pt]
&=\biggl(10\% \times \frac{1}{1+0.60}\biggl) + \biggl(4.6\% \times \frac{0.60}{1+0.60}\biggl)\\[12pt]
&=\biggl(0.1 \times \frac{1}{1.60}\biggl) + \biggl(0.046 \times \frac{0.60}{1.60}\biggl)\\[12pt]

&=\biggl(0.1 \times0.625\biggl) + \biggl(0.046 \times 0.375\biggl)\\[12pt]
&=0.0625+0.01725\\[7pt]
&=0.079\\[7pt]
&=7.9\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the weighted average cost of capital of debt-equity ratio is $\boxed{7.9\%}$

Second, we have to find out the actual weighted average cost of capital which we denote with $AW$, where the weighted average cost of capital of debt-equity ratio $WD$ is $7.9\%$ and the additional rate $AR$ is $3\%$

$$\begin{align*}
AW&=WD + AR\\[7pt]
&=7.9\%+3\%\\[7pt]
&=0.079+0.03\\[7pt]
&=0.109\\[7pt]
&=10.9\%
\end{align*}$$

So, the actual weighted average cost of capital is $\boxed{10.9\%}$

Finally, let's find out the current value of tax savings which we denote with $CT$, where the after-tax cash savings $AC$ is $\$2,300,000$, the actual weighted average cost of capital $AW$ is $10.9\%$ and the growth rate $GR$ is $2\%$

$$\begin{align*}
CT&=\frac{AC}{AW -GR}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{2,300,000}{10.9\% -2\%}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{2,300,000}{0.109 -0.02}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{2,300,000}{0.089}\\[12pt]
&=\$25,842,696.63

\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the current value of tax savings is $\boxed{\$25,842,696.63}$
